history.content:
I've only taken like half of these, but I can give you a fair amount of advice. Those classes span a pretty wide range of topics, and depending on what you end up doing, only some will be useful.

EE 128 is a control theory class. While you do a bit on hardware, it's very much not the focus of the class, nor should it be. It's probably the #1 thing you should take if you want to actually do robotics/control (instead of implement things on robots).

EECS 106A is pretty high on the engineering stack. It covers kinematics and dynamics, and a bit of high level control. You do a lot of high-level implementation on hardware. This class essentially covers the interface between your AI/overall state machine and your low-level control. I like it a lot (but I'm very biased)

EECS 106B covers current research in robotics (but not AI stuff). It's really cool imo (but I'm still very biased) but is very hard. You learn a lot of very modern robotics stuff and implement some papers as lab projects.

EECS 149 is a level lower and covers all the RTOS stuff you need to directly communicate with hardware. I don't do much of that stuff so I didn't end up taking it, but the new iteration of the labs is supposed to be pretty good.

ME 135 is similar to 149 except it's taught in LabView. Don't take it unless you want to spend your life making test stands for big hardware companies (just my opinion as a hater of LabView).

EE 192 is yet lower and covers the actual electronics/hardware needed in robotics. It's a lot of work and there's a ton of circuit design and soldering and such. I think that this is a great class if you have a lot of time and don't know much about mechatronics. If you already have a reasonable amount of knowledge, it doesn't go any faster and you don't learn much so I don't recommend it.

ME 102B is kinda similar to EE 192 except the project is open-ended. It's a lot of fun.

ME 119 is totally unrelated to traditional robotics. MEMS is cool (to some people), but essentially everything is different. My friends who've taken it enjoyed it though.

I'm not sure about BioE 105 or IB 135.

If you're doing data science and want to combine data science with robotics, 106A/B is probably the way to go, since that's what you need to know to apply ML/AI stuff to hardware. ME 135 could also be useful for test stand design if you want to do that. The rest of the courses are very EE focused and I'm not sure they'd be worthwhile to you.

I listed out the classes required for the data science robotics domain emphasis, because its not that easy to find people who have taken these classes :(

I currently am going to take EE192 and EE149, but I am flexible in which ones to take. I was deciding between the robotics DE and the applied math one, and settled on robotics because I like

robots! However, I would like a little advice on these classes (192, 149, and whatever else you may know about). What are those classes like? Did you enjoy them? Was getting enrolled difficult?Would you recommend a different set of classes for me instead? Thanks. 

  • BIO ENG 105. Engineering Devices 1 (4 units) [MATH 53, PHYS 7A+7B]

  • BIO ENG / EECS C106A. Introduction to Robotics (4 units) [EE 120]

  • BIO ENG / EECS C106B. Robotic Manipulation and Interaction (4 units) [BIO ENG C106A]

  • EECS 149. Introduction to Embedded Systems (4 units) [CS 70, CS 61ABC, EE 16A+16B]

  • EL ENG 192. Mechatronic Design Laboratory (4 units) [EE 16A+16B, CS 61ABC, EE 120]

  • INTEGBI C135L. The Mechanics of Organisms (4 units) [intro physics & biology]

  • MEC ENG 119. Introduction to MEMS (Microelectromechanical Systems) (3 units) [EE16A, PHYS 7A+7B]

  • MEC ENG C134 / EL ENG C128. Feedback Control Systems (4 units) [EE 16A, EE 120]

  • MEC ENG 135. Design of Microprocessor-Based Mechanical Systems (4 units) [ENGIN 7]
history.subject: Questions about a couple of classes that are harder to find advice for (robotics classes)
